1: Job spoke again and said this:\q1
2:
"I wish that I could be as I was previously\q2 during the years when God took care of me.
\q1
3:
During those years, it was as though God's lamp shone on me\q2 and gave me light while I walked in the darkness.


\q1
4:
At that time I was young and strong,\q2 and because God was my friend, he protected where I lived.
\q1
5:
Almighty God was with me during those years\q2 when all my children were around me.
\q1
6:
My herds provided me with plenty of milk,\q2 and streams of oil flowed from the rock where my servants pressed the olives.


\q1
7:
Whenever I went to the place where the elders gathered at the city gate,\q2 I sat down with them,
\q1
8:
and when the young men saw me, they stepped aside respectfully,\q2 and the old men also stood respectfully.


\q1
9: The leaders of the people used to stop talking,\q1
10:
and even the most important men became quiet\q2 and stopped talking in order to hear me speak to them.


\q1
11:
When they all heard what I told them,\q2 they said good things about me.
\q1 When they saw me, they always praised me
\q1
12:
because I had helped those who were poor when they cried out for help,\q2 and because I aided those who had no fathers, those who had no one else to help them.
\q1
13:
Those who were suffering and about to die praised me,\q2 and I caused widows to sing joyfully, because I helped them.


\q1
14:
I always acted justly;\q2 my actions were like a robe that I wore and like a turban that was wrapped around my head.
\q1
15:
It was as though I myself saw for blind people\q2 and walked for people who were lame.
\q1
16:
I was like a father to the poor people,\q2 and in the courts I defended those who were strangers to me.


\q1
17:
I made wicked people stop oppressing others; it was like someone who breaks the teeth of wild animals\q2 and forces them to drop their victims from their teeth.
\q1
18:
At that time I thought, 'Surely I will live in peace until I am very old,\q2 and I will die at home with my family.
\q1
19:
I am like a tree whose roots reach down into the water\q2 and whose branches become wet with dew each night.


\q1
20:
People always honor me,\q2 and I am always strong like a new bow.'
\q1
21:
When I spoke, people waited to hear what I would say;\q2 they remained silent until I advised them what they should do.
\q1
22:
After I finished speaking, they did not say anymore;\q2 it was as though my words fell on their ears like drops of rain.


\q1
23:
They waited for me to speak as they wait for rain;\q2 they liked what I said as farmers appreciate the final rain in the spring before the dry season.
\q1
24:
When they were sad, I smiled at them to encourage them;\q2 they became encouraged when they saw my cheerful face.


\q1
25:
I was their leader, and I decided what things would be good for them to do;\q2 I was among them like a king who is among his troops;
\q2 I was like someone who comforts others who are mourning."
